poem_title: TO THE COUNTESS of EXETER, Playing on the Lute.
author: Matthew Prior

lines.line_text: Charms You have, from what high Race You sprung,
Have been the pleasing Subjects of my Song:
Unskill'd and young, yet something still I writ,
Of  Beauty join'd to  Wit.
But when You please to show the lab'ring ,
What greater Theme Your Musick can produce;
My babling Praises I repeat no more;
But hear, rejoice, stand silent, and adore.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Charms You have, from what high Race You sprung,
Have been the pleasing Subjects of my Song:
Unskill'd and young, yet something still I writ,
Of  Beauty join'd to  Wit.
But when You please to show the lab'ring ,
What greater Theme Your Musick can produce;
My babling Praises I repeat no more;
But hear, rejoice, stand silent, and adore.

lines.line_text: The  thus, first gazing on the Sun,
Admir'd, how high 'twas plac'd, how bright it shone:
But, as his Pow'r was known, their Thoughts were rais'd;
And soon They worship'd, what at first They prais'd.

stanzas.stanza_text:
The  thus, first gazing on the Sun,
Admir'd, how high 'twas plac'd, how bright it shone:
But, as his Pow'r was known, their Thoughts were rais'd;
And soon They worship'd, what at first They prais'd.

lines.line_text: Glory lives in  Song;
And  Verse keeps Fair  young.
That as in Birth, in Beauty You excell,
The  might dictate, and the Poet tell:
Your Art no other Art can speak; and You,
To show how well You play, must play anew:
Your Musick's Pow'r Your Musick must disclose;
For what Light is, 'tis only Light that shows.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Glory lives in  Song;
And  Verse keeps Fair  young.
That as in Birth, in Beauty You excell,
The  might dictate, and the Poet tell:
Your Art no other Art can speak; and You,
To show how well You play, must play anew:
Your Musick's Pow'r Your Musick must disclose;
For what Light is, 'tis only Light that shows.

lines.line_text: Strange Force of Harmony, that thus controuls
Our Thoughts, and turns and sanctifies our Souls:
While with it's utmost Art Your Sex could move
Our Wonder only, or at best our Love:
You far above Both these Your GOD did place;
That Your high Pow'r might worldly Thoughts destroy;
That with Your Numbers You our Zeal might raise,
And, like Himself, communicate Your Joy.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Strange Force of Harmony, that thus controuls
Our Thoughts, and turns and sanctifies our Souls:
While with it's utmost Art Your Sex could move
Our Wonder only, or at best our Love:
You far above Both these Your GOD did place;
That Your high Pow'r might worldly Thoughts destroy;
That with Your Numbers You our Zeal might raise,
And, like Himself, communicate Your Joy.

lines.line_text: When to Your Native Heav'n You shall repair,
And with Your Presence crown the Blessings there;
Your Lute may wind it's Strings but little higher,
To tune their Notes to that immortal Quire.
Your Art is perfect here: Your Numbers do,
More than our Books, make the rude Atheist know,
That there's a Heav'n, by what He hears below.

stanzas.stanza_text:
When to Your Native Heav'n You shall repair,
And with Your Presence crown the Blessings there;
Your Lute may wind it's Strings but little higher,
To tune their Notes to that immortal Quire.
Your Art is perfect here: Your Numbers do,
More than our Books, make the rude Atheist know,
That there's a Heav'n, by what He hears below.

lines.line_text: As in some Piece, while  his Skill exprest,
A cunning Angel came, and drew the rest:
So, when You play, some Godhead does impart
Harmonious Aid; Divinity helps Art:
Some Cherub finishes what You begun,
And to a Miracle improves a Tune.

stanzas.stanza_text:
As in some Piece, while  his Skill exprest,
A cunning Angel came, and drew the rest:
So, when You play, some Godhead does impart
Harmonious Aid; Divinity helps Art:
Some Cherub finishes what You begun,
And to a Miracle improves a Tune.

lines.line_text: To burning  when frantick  play'd,
Viewing that Face, no more He had survey'd
The raging Flames; but struck with strange Surprize,
Confest them less than Those of  Eyes:
But had He heard Thy Lute, He soon had found
His Rage eluded, and his Crime atton'd:
Thine, like  Hand, had wak'd the Stone,
And from Destruction call'd the rising Town:
Malice to Musick had been forc'd to yield;
Nor could He Burn so fast, as Thou could'st Build.

stanzas.stanza_text:
To burning  when frantick  play'd,
Viewing that Face, no more He had survey'd
The raging Flames; but struck with strange Surprize,
Confest them less than Those of  Eyes:
But had He heard Thy Lute, He soon had found
His Rage eluded, and his Crime atton'd:
Thine, like  Hand, had wak'd the Stone,
And from Destruction call'd the rising Town:
Malice to Musick had been forc'd to yield;
Nor could He Burn so fast, as Thou could'st Build.
